reviews.review_title: The Unparalleled Lubitsch Touch in a Genuine Romantic Comedy Classic
reviews.content: Ernst Lubitsch was a master of the unexpected comedy element, something so idiosyncratic that it defies serious explanation. This charming 1940 classic epitomizes his style so well that the subsequent remakes appear either marginally pointless (the musical 1949 version, "In the Good Old Summertime") or excruciatingly formulaic (1998's e-mail update, "You've Got Mail"). This is a wondrous and gentle romantic comedy starring James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan.Written by Samson Raphaelson, the soufflé-light plot involves the staff at Matuschek & Company, a Budapest leather goods emporium run by its curmudgeonly namesake. Head clerk Alfred Kralik is on the management track when Klara Novak impresses Matuschek enough to get hired as a new sales clerk. Inevitably, Alfred and Klara are at odds with each other from the start, but we discover they are also unwitting pen-pals who are falling in love without having met. Meanwhile, Matuschek suspects his wife of having an affair and suspects Alfred, whom he immediately terminates. When it turns out not to be Alfred but his despised co-worker, the bootlicking toady Ferencz Vadas, Matuschek commits a desperate act which forces Alfred to become the interim store manager. The busy Christmas season provides the appropriate setting to resolve all the plot strands.What strikes me most about the film is not the actual storyline, which borders on predictable and contrived upon closer inspection, but the way Lubitsch and the cast bring it to life in such subtly memorable ways. Young and assured, Stewart gives one of my favorite of his performances as Alfred, and with her buttery speaking voice, Sullavan provides the perfect match as Klara. Their chemistry is palpable and makes the subsequent remakes feel comparatively pallid. The Wizard himself, Frank Morgan portrays Matuschek with alternate bluster and poignancy. The other players also make vivid impressions, in particular, Lubitsch regular Felix Bressart as the timid Pirovitch, a cast-against-type Joseph Schildkraut as the slimy Vadas, and William Tracy as the resourceful errand boy Pepi. The print transfer on the 2002 DVD is blessedly clean, and there are two extras offered, the original theatrical trailer and a 1940 short, "The Miracle of Sound" about the impact of the sound revolution at MGM.

Although the plot of the movie is rather predictable the acting of Stewart and Sullavan still holds up. The movie drags a little at some points but in general it keeps a rather decent pace. Some events are a pleasent suprise in the story but they feel a little misplaced. Stewart brings, as always, a certain amount of joy, believability and sensitivity to his character. Sullavan is well casts and performs quite well however in some scenes she lacks a powerfull attitude behind her words.
Although a small role, the character development of Pepi, well played by William Tracy, gives a refreshing dimension to the movie.Some would call this a Christmas movie but I would say that it just so happends to take place around the holidays. Overall a fun and heartwarming but rather typical movie that doesn't surprise very much.

reviews.review_title: Charming Christmas comedy right around the corner
reviews.content: Like many folks who've seen "You've Got Mail", I'd heard of "The Restaurant Around the Corner", but had never gotten around to seeing it until Christmas Eve, when it ran on TCM. What a gem! The hallmark of a great old movie, like a jazz or country album, is not the headliners but the supporting cast. Jimmy Stewart is so, well, Stewartesque as the senior employee of Matuschek and company, a gift shop anticipating a busy Christmas, and Frank Morgan, his boss, makes you forget all about The Wizard of Oz and almost convinced me that rich people really are worse off than those who have to work for them, when he suspects his wife of an affair with one of his employees. Margaret Sullavan stirs the shop's crew when she manages to sell a hard-to-move item to one of the shop's hardest customers, and she and Stewart create a delicious love/hate relationship that was imitated, not matched, by Ryan and Hanks decades later. The cast includes Sir Joseph Schildkraut, one of the earliest Oscar-winning supporting actors, and his role as Vadas, a co-worker to Stewart, is marvelous; at once mousy (whenever he hears the boss asking for an "honest opinion", he disappears as if the building is on fire) and fatherly, offering both Stewart and Sullavan advice on their love lives. The rest of the supporting cast is not as well known as the leads, but equally as delightful. Grace Hayle (not even credited) plays "plump woman" for perhaps the 100th time in her prolific career as a character actress. The movie exhibits the "Lubitsch touch", and sixty years after its release it still has moments that will make you laugh out loud. If you aren't used to watching movies from the 30s and 40s, you might not be used to the long sequences that, today, would be accompanied by soundtracks; likewise, some of the entrances and exits (walking into the scene after the camera has started) may appear dated. But that is part of the film's charm, for me at any rate.I'm sorry it's taken me so long to discover this happy little movie. Look for it year round, or at Christmastime.

reviews.review_title: "...if you prick us, do we not bleed?..."
reviews.content: How exquisitely does director Ernst Lubitsch glean every infinitesimal nuance from each word , deed, and interaction. A group of flawed, doomed, people striving for their place in the sun ere eternal darkness descends, has their being in a haberdashery shop in pre-war pre-Holocaust Eastern Europe. It it us, it is we, here depicted with a symathetic eye. We justly weep for ourselves.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful Original and Equally Engaging Remake
reviews.content: I cannot decide which version of this story I like better (completely discounting the third version of "You've Got Mail") -- the original with James Stewart and Margaret Sullivan or the remake with Judy Garland and Van Johnson. Each has its own identity and is not confused with the other. The plot is classic and universally understood and in that respect will never go out of style. Obviously it can be successfully placed in a contemporary setting, but the heart of the relationship between the two main characters should not be squeezed into the present day in such a manner that dilutes both the characters and the story, as was done so shamelessly in "You've Got Mail."

Speak of The Shop Around the Corner in contemporary times, and you're more than likely to be greeted by blank looks until you revise its moniker to 'You've Got (Snail) Mail' ("Ohhhh! THAT one!"). But, while director Ernst Lubitsch's classical rom-com may have to contend with its '90s remake for pop culture recognition, it's easily charming and delightful enough to warrant, at the very least, comparable adulation. Distinctly more demure and gentle than the masses of sparkier screwball comedies in vogue at its time, Lubitsch's film strips itself of any such pretences, striving instead for a softer, infinitely more vulnerable play for unfettered emotion, seasoned with knowing wit. His sentiment pays off, as the film remains an abiding holiday classic, almost too lovable to resist. Adapted from Hungarian playwright Miklós László's work Parfumerie, Lubitsch's retaining the Budapest setting with transplanted American actors may take some acclimatizing to (perhaps Lubitsch was content to have a more heartwarming link to Europe than all of the wartime atrocities cluttering the newsreels - notice the conspicuous absence of any politics or world events), but it only adds to the film's nostalgic, somewhat anachronistic charm. With a dreamy, unassuming pace, Lubitsch allows his characters to breathe, carefully delineating the lives, fears, hopes and dreams of each staff member of the titular department store's staff with tender compassion before allowing the centrepiece love story to build amidst them with slow, teasing playfulness. Certainly, the film has its blips of alarming darkness that suggest Lubitsch was too attuned to the sociopolitical climate to create an entirely vacuous fairy tale, but they are painted with the same observant humanity and care as the rest of the film's naturalistic character beats. And if the corresponding friction inherent in the film's Much Ado About Nothing twist may come with occasional whiffs of contrivance or excessive convenience, the mischievous, disarming sweetness with which they weave tantalizingly closer to one another more than makes up for it. The film's 'first date' scene alone is so unforgettably clever and savagely funny that even You've Got Mail couldn't resist borrowing it almost shot-for-shot, and winning the raucous laughs of a whole new generation of viewers. Still, it's the indelible chemistry of James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan, one of the most reliable pairings of the classical era, that elevate the film to the level of classic. The two play off each other with consummate ease, segueing from caustic, prank- filled, screwball-lite barbs and fireworks to embers of affection seamlessly, and Sullavan's fast-talking, peppery vigour proves the perfectly adorable foil for Stewart's twinkling, huffy bluster. Supporting them, Felix Bressart practically embodies the film's gentle, winking spirit as their kindly coworker, Joseph Schildkraut is so oily he practically glistens as the store's resident fink, William Tracy is so loudly comedic he practically seems to have cockily strolled in from another film entirely (but remains irresistibly funny nonetheless), while Frank Morgan hits the perfect cocktail of imposingly obtuse with a secret heart of gold as the shop's perennially harried owner. It's hugely refreshing, even for the early 1940s, to find a film so straightforwardly pleasant and enjoyable, but Lubitsch's deft hand has the film bursting with simple but robust charm. Resonantly heartwarming comedy and romance, an undercurrent of melancholy stripped of any histrionics and with only the gentlest indulgence of saccharine Hollywood convention, The Shop Around the Corner's abiding sweetness continues to make it a welcome discovery or revisitation, whether as a holiday watch, or a means of unwinding with a smile year-round. And if its success had anything to do to stem the flow of tacky, ornamental music boxes? All the better. -8/10

The Shop Around the Corner is the movie You've Got Mail was based on - however, it has a much darker tone. The Christmas element only came in during the last half-hour or so, but still, it was a fun holiday movie. I still don't know why they decided to set it in Budapest, though.

reviews.review_title: Much better film than it's remake 'You've Got Mail'
reviews.content: This film shows it's character's decency in his behavior towards his boss and in the fact that he isn't already hooked up with another girl, playing a game of toying with someone's heart by sending her love letters.The same is true for the female lead's character who imagines the letter writer as different from who he turns out to be, but isn't with another guy and looking for 'love on the side' Great give and take in the dialog back and forth between the two in this romantic comedy. It even dealt with issues that were ahead of it's time, such as attempted suicide.Sadly, the remake of this movie (trying to put it in the modern era) of "You Got Mail", the characters are about as different from the originals as you can get. Any similarity to this fine movie is purely coincidental.Would be interesting to read the play/book this was based on.

I can't do better with this review than others have done, and I wholeheartedly agree with everything they have said. This is a perfect movie, truly--the directing, acting, editing, writing are all flawless. For an unexplained reason, I have just finished watching the movie five nights in a row and I have enjoyed it every time. The scenes between Margaret Sullivan and Jimmy Stewart are so delightful that I hold my breath to watch them. Especially Margaret Sullivan is so much fun to watch as she puts Jimmy Stewart down and is so charming in doing so that you can't help but love her. The whole cast is outstanding. The young man who plays Pepi almost steals the movie. What he does with the role is so rich and full and multi-layered and unique in its portrayal and interpretation. But they are all perfectly cast and work together so well. I don't understand why this movie didn't get multiple Oscar nominations in 1940, including Best Picture.

Purely comical orientated movies weren't a that common thing in the '40's. it makes this movie an all the more refreshing and delightful one.It's a simple movie, with a simple story, that at all times is kept pleasant to watch. But that doesn't mean that the story is not a well written one. Often though of course most elements in it are generic and predictable, it is still all brought in a fresh way, which makes the movie still original enough in its genre and definitely for its time. The dialog is especially well written, as you would expect from a '40's movie, when writers understood their craft. It even in the end has a great Christmas spirit in it, which adds all the more to the pleasant warm feeling of the movie.To me it seemed pretty redundant though that the movie was set in Hungary. It added nothing to the story or characters and worked only confusing, since the characters all had Hungarian names but of course were all talking in plain English. I understand they let this movie take place in Hungary because it was based on an Hungarian play but movie-wise it didn't added anything. This was something the later movie versions of the play "In the Good Old Summertime" and "You've Got Mail" understood.James Stewart wasn't really known for his leading comical or romantic roles, so his role in this movie is quite surprising and he does a good job at it as well. He still looked so very young in this and in his first scene I didn't even realized it was him, simply because I didn't recognized him. The rest of the cast isn't that well known but the movie is filled with many and delightful characters, that are by no means standard or one dimensional. The many characters within the movie definitely adds to the movie its fun.It's not the sort of comedy that will make you laugh out loud but it's more the sort of movie that will put a smile on your face, all the way through. 8/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

I think the reviews are very generous here .Reminds of " it's a wonderful life " in the way it's filmed .Although nowhere near as memorable .Enjoyable but the story is pretty dull in all truth .Watching it once will be enough.

reviews.review_title: Lovely love story, well acted by all.
reviews.content: It took me 58 years to see this film. I saw it the day after I saw "You Got Mail" and I thought I'd like to see the original on video. I'll take the original. In contrast to the Nora Ephron/Tom Hanks/Meg Ryan picture, "Shop" is not full of witty one-liners and hip 90's types. It is a straightforward love story with a twist, well played by the leads (James Stewart, Margaret Sullivan) and various character actors, including a kindly Frank Morgan. The plot is pretty well known by now - the leads don't get along at all, each believing they have the ideal partner in an anonymous correspondence. We think we know how it will all end, but it is carried forward beautifully. Mostly underplayed by the actors, it is a wonderful story, wonderfully depicted. And when was the last time you heard fellow workers refer to themselves as Mr. or Miss so and so?

I challenge you to find a bad performance in this wonderful film. Perfect acting. Perfect direction. Felix Bressart (Pirovitch) is so amazing. Frank Morgan is at his absolute best. I could go on and on. Jimmy Stewart proves why he is the best "Movie Star" ever. Keep an eye out for a gem of a performance by William Tracy as Pepi. Don't bother renting this movie--Just buy it! You'll watch it over and over again.

Festive atmosphere flavored family drama, spontaneous love, heartfelt comedy and healthy humor. Director Lubitsch's film spice with warm and everyday human subjects. THE SHOP AROUND THE CORNER" is a pleasant place with a lot of respect and charm. The film is a bit slow. I think that this approach is intentional, because this looks more realistic. The story is more or less everyday. The love affair or the love of the main character are strange spices in the story. Both changes in the daily routine of the protagonists and their views on life. Lonely hearts connected a piece of paper. True. It is fascinating to watch how the director deftly mixes comedy, drama and romance. In this film does not lose the thread, the atmosphere remains the same and only the changing characters. Characterization of the characters is very interesting. Frank Morgan as Hugo Matuschek owns the shop and he is benevolent dictator. James Stewart as Alfred Kralik is a workaholic and a perfectionist and very lonely character who is difficult to adapt. Margaret Sullavan as Klara Novak is safe but lonely. The woman in which the conflict her own and outer world. Felix Bressart as Pirovitch, the man who in life has two stations. Work and family. Two of the greatest love and the two biggest fear. A friend in need. The voice of reason and peace.The film that appeals to the Christmas atmosphere.

reviews.review_title: A perfect Christmas feel good movie
reviews.content: Two colleagues can't stand each other at work, but (without knowing) are very close corresponding with each other.After "Ninochka" (1939) Ernst Lubitsch made another romantic comedy within a year. Nearly 60 years later Nora Ephron made a remake with "You've got mail" (1998), substituting the e-mail for the letter. She did not reach the same standard as Lubitsch, nor did "You've got mail" equal "Sleepless in Seattle" (1993), her earlier film with Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan."The shop around the corner" is situated in the christmas shopping season. Given het happy end it is the perfect Christmas feel good movie. My sugesstion to television channels would be to alternate it with "It's a wonderful life" (1946, Frank Capra), in stead of broadcasting last mentioned picture every year.James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan are doing a wonderful job as the two colleagues. Frank Morgan as shop owner Hugo Matuschek is however the icing on the cake. In the beginning of the movie he is the enlighted despot asking everybody about his "honest opinion" while in reality he only wants a confirmation of his own opinion. At the end however he steals everybody's heart (at least mine) when, after being ill, he returns to the shop, looks through the shop window and is sincerely delighted to see the hustle and bustle in the shop.

reviews.review_title: This is an underrated holiday gem that is an absolute must see
reviews.content: The Shop Around the Corner (1940) is a holiday gem that I recently watched on HBOMAX. The storyline follows a market store that has a new young lady join the staff, a young man who has fallen for a girl he's never met but writes letters to and a shop owner with troubles at home. The young man and the new female employee struggle to get along and the young man feels the owner is treating him strangely. The three worlds are about to explode and ruin everyone's Christmas unless they can band together like a family and save their relationships.This movie is directed by Ernst Lubitsch (Heaven Can Wait) and stars James Stewart (Vertigo), Margaret Sullavan (Three Comrades), Frank Morgan (The Wizard of Oz), Joseph Schildkraut (The Diary of Anne Frank), Felix Bressart (To be or Not to Be) and William Tracy (Terry and the Pirates).The characters in this picture are wonderfully written, perfectly cast and brilliantly delivered to the audience. The dialogue is very good and the dynamics between the characters are fascinating. The film has many unpredictable elements even if the end is predictable. There's some really good subplots, especially the owners wife storyline. The character evolution is good as is the impact of circumstances on the shop and shop employees. The ultimate resolve will make you smile.Overall, this is an underrated holiday gem that is an absolute must see. I would score this a 9/10 and strongly recommend it.

A good solid film, many times re-made. Not of a genre that's a personal favorite of mine, but it is a well made example of this type. I enjoyed Frank Morgan's character quite a lot too. Basically I'd say it's a comedy of human manners.I didn't think Sullivan and Stewart had a very convincing romantic chemistry. But it's a pleasant film and has some funny scenes. The photography is exceptional, and Lubitsch's direction as always is finely balanced. He always gives you just enough and not too much, whether it be "corn" or drama or anything.Stewart is also very good in the role, I was surprised he could play so "young".

Ernst Lubitsch directed this workplace comedy set in Budapest, Hungary. Alfred Kralik(played by James Stewart) is a long-term salesman to the Matuschek company run by Hugo(played by Frank Morgan). One day, he impulsively hires Klara Novak(played by Margaret Sullavan) who clashes with Alfred, though unknowingly they have also become pen pals, and are falling in love! Things take a sad turn when Alfred is mistakenly believed to be having an affair with Hugo's wife, leading to his termination. Devastated, Alfred decides how he can tell his pen pal that is unemployed, while he figures out a way to get his old job back. Funny and sentimental comedy romance has a good cast and direction to make it a holiday favorite.

Ernst Lubitsch's comedies ("Ninotchka", "To be or not to be") have simple arguments that can easily charm us. This occurs, among other factors, due to the charisma of its characters, the structure of the stories and the personal touch of the filmmaker. That must be why, especially from the 1980s onwards, it is possible to observe references to his productions in the most diverse romantic comedies. In "Message To You", by Nora Ephron, it is possible, for example, to notice an update of "A Loja da Esquina", a 1940 comedy starring James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan.Based on the eponymous play by Miklós Laszló, the plot follows Alfred Kralik (Stewart), an experienced salesman for Matuschek, a gift shop in Budapest. Kralik corresponds anonymously with a young woman, unaware that this is Klara Novak (Sullavan), the newly hired saleswoman at the store with whom he does not have a friendly relationship. The setting of the film takes place, mostly, inside the store, which makes it possible to know the story of other characters such as the owner (Frank Morgan) and Pirovitch (Felix Bressart). More than that, we are invited to be with them.Between a whisper and another by Pirovitch and Kralik, a cynical discussion between the protagonist couple and Matuschek's abrupt interruptions, the camera by William H. Daniels ("Vale das Bonecas") makes us the third member of the scene, which contributes to create intimacy and perpetuate the charisma of the characters. Lubitsch's direction calls the viewer to witness the stories told in the store. Without resorting to exaggerations or mushy artifices common to this cinematographic genre, the German director does an unpretentious job, which employs in the group of salesmen a reflection of the world between wars.REFLECTION OF A SAD WORLDAlthough the narrative is constructed within a comic and Christmas atmosphere, it also accuses the psychosocial state to which it is inserted. One can notice, in the faces of the characters and in the dialogues, the loneliness, melancholy and collective hopelessness resulting from the initial tensions of the Second World War added to the crisis of 1929.Metaphorically, the script signed by Samson Raphaelson uses proximity to Christmas celebrations to nurture a dramatic arc in which all the characters are emotionally isolated and react to it, even if imperceptibly. For this reason, issues related to fear, limitations and disappointments are so present. In this scope, the linear narrative and without major twists and turns represents the existential condition of this historical period.Lubitsch built a small masterpiece in "A Loja da Esquina". Its round and charming story reveals a simple and smooth film that is much more than a classic romantic comedy: it is a portrait of its time.

reviews.review_title: I Love this film ...it should have swept the Oscars.
reviews.content: This is by far my favorite Christmas themed film. The Bishop's wife is a close second but I love this film and can watch it over and over. Every performance is perfect.If Sullavan had a volatile temper then somehow she used that to great affect.....Stewart is so young and so appealing. Stewart's hurt is tenable at her mean put down of him. They are perfect. Frank Morgan is wonderful. I was amazed that the actor who played Otto Frank , Schildkraut is the fop in this picture....and an odious character. I can't praise this film enough.....my colleague introduced this film to me and we showed it to HS students. They responded well though they HATE black and white films. So that says something for its timelessness and it enduring appeal.

This was great. The happenings of a Budapest department store is told with intelligent dialogue and great characters. James Stewart is so likeable here. The film is set in Budapest with American actors and at no point do you actually feel like you are in Hungary, some of the plot is predictable, it is sentimental and when you actually analyse the blind date aspect of the film it is a bit creepy but none of this matters because the film has an everlasting charm and nothing feels forced. A great film overall.

This is a perfect and delightful movie. Jimmy Stewart actually plays to the role and gives one of his better performances. There is something whimsical yet simple about the story line of two people working in the same shop, and unbeknownst to the other, exchanging love letters. While engaged in the shop, they are antagonist, comparing each negatively to the fictional letters they receive.The story takes on a darker more ominous tone of despair and loneliness, highlighted by the Christmas season. (A darkness not so apparent in the musical remake of 1949 with Judy Garland and Van Johnson, "In the Good Old Summertime.")The writing is tight, the lines believable, the scenario plausible. And the love story charming. This is a delightful and charming movie.

reviews.review_title: The best Christmas movie of them all
reviews.content: If you asked a bunch of people to name their favorite Christmas movie (and a lot of them were 50 or older), then nobody would be surprised if Frank Capra's "It's a Wonderful Life" finished at the top of the list. But let's not forget another truly wonderful, unforgettable holiday movie also starring Jimmy Stewart, Ernst Lubitsch's "The Shop Around the Corner." Capra employs the device of an angel named Clarence trying to earn his wings to help prove to the character played by Stewart his own inherent goodness and worth. But Lubitsch has a simpler and less supernatural approach to conveying his holiday message: pen pals who've fallen in love without ever having seen one another. Both films are fundamentally about the power of love, in its many and various forms, to renew, redeem, and restore meaning to life. As was Capra's way, "Life" takes the more melodramatic & sentimental approach, whereas "Shop" is a bit melancholy and remarkably unsentimental in making its point. Many may continue to prefer the former, but I prefer the latter approach without reservation. Both are treasures, to be sure, during the holiday season or indeed at any time of year.

This slick heart-warmer floats above the ocean of cliched romantic comedies. The punchy pacey script and polished acting make it stand out on one hand. On the other hand dark undertones, lurk beneath the surface. The protagonists in a variety of ways vie to deceive themselves about their position in life whilst trying to hold down a poorly paid job in the middle of a recession, simply to keep living.The two lovers to be make fantastical, successful, alter egos for themselves in their letters as extravagantly as Rudy acts up after his promotion. Meanwhile, Matuschek happily deludes himself to the point of ruin about his wife, pouring money via her into the dandy Vadas' jewelry box.  The shop itself sells vanities to the affected middle classes epitomised by the musical cigarette boxes.  Pirovitch alone is happy with his simple family life acting as a counterpoint to the self-deluding fantasies of the rest of the cast. This could be a set up for a tragedy, and indeed seems to be heading that way when Stewart looses his job and trades barbed comments with Sullivan. But we are offered the chance of redemption.  Rudy saves Matuschek from the bullet, Vadas is uncovered (by perhaps an almost revelingly cruel Stewart) and we swing back into romance territory.  The underpaid workers are happy selling their knick-knacks again, the tills ring for Christmas and romance fills the air, their salvation, or another happy deception?

Ernst Lubitsch is rightly regarded as one of the great directors of early cinema and this is his best, a sublime comedy-drama focusing on a group of employees working in a gift shop in Budapest. Stewart and Sullavan are wonderful as co-workers who fall in hate at first sight. The excellent supporting cast includes Morgan (shortly after playing the Wizard of Oz) as the owner of the shop, Bressart (looking a lot like Groucho Marx) as Stewart's kindly friend, and Tracy as a Smart Alec gofer aspiring to be a clerk. The characters are all human, the dialog is witty, and the script is top-notch. A funny and touching love story, this is a perfect example of the so-called Lubitsch touch.

early Stewart film has him somewhat in support of Sullivan...he does well but appears to be a tad too young for the role, as fledgling Salesman in a small but successful shop in Budapest, who learns that an adversarial co-worker is actually the girl he has been writing to! the shop and environment ring of small town America...I did miss some of the early scenes...so I spent a lot of viewing time thinking I was watching a Frank Capra film! it's said that the '90s YOU'VE GOT (E-)MAIL is the "remake" of this 1940 film and strangely, Tom Hanks is every bit as dull as Jimmy Stewart is here.just like so many of today's films, this entry runs on too long and blows past many opportunities to inject some liveliness, some zaniness into the stilted proceedings.I walked away from the TV for about two minutes thinking the film was quickly winding down after the scene when the Shop's aging owner, visiting at Christmas eve, in his recuperation from a severe breakdown after learning his wife was messing around in the stockroom, takes the opportunity to invite the newest hiree, a 17 year old delivery boy, to a Christmas dinner.Thought the movie should end there, as the two walk up the snowy street, and see Jimmy and Margaret in an embrace, under a street light. But....no. More tentative romance with the two former pen pals.

This movie has spawned new movies, "You've got Mail" and one of the best Braodway Musicals ever, "She Loves Me." Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan are just modern day versions of the original love story.It's charm is classic. The irony of people who love one another but do not know it is marvelous. IT should be in the top 250.The real classic that grew from this movie is Sheldon Harnick and Jerry Bock's musical, "She Loves Me." Watch for this show to return to Broadway and be named Best Musical at the Tony's.There are so many fans of the original movie and the "You've Got Mail" facsimile that a Broadway revival of "She Love Me" cannot fail.In the meantime, the original is a great, great movie.

Ernst Lubitsch's Hollywood Budapest of the mind where, despite economic hard times, consumers spend happily at Christmas while true love wins out and there is not a Nazi in sight definitely appealed to 1940 isolationist America. That it still appeals to 2023 semi isolationist America is, of course, due to its director's as well as its screenwriter, Samson Raphaelson's, ability to keep the light (i.e. James Stewart/Margaret Sullivan) and the dark (i.e. Frank Morgan's lonely cuckold) in perfect, comic balance so that the schmaltz does not overwhelm the realism or vice versa. That I ultimately prefer the dark side is not due to any fault of Lubitsch but rather to my indifference toward Sullivan as a comedic actress. Give it an A minus.PS...As for the two remakes, I would definitely choose "You've Got Mail", even though it jettisons Morgan's character, over the insufferably cute "Good Old Summertime", even though it's got Garland.

reviews.review_title: The Other Jimmy Stewart Christmas Movie
reviews.content: The Shop Around the Corner was the first Ernst Lubitsch film I saw and as soon as the characters started interacting with each other I instantly knew this was a guy who knew how to handle dialogue in what is referred to as the so-called 'Lubitsch Touch'. With such levels of subtly, this is the kind of movie that needs to be watched multiple times and gets better every time you do so. Often there will be a verbal joke in which I am unaware it even is a joke and it will take a few seconds to catch onto it. Most of Lubitsch's films were set in Europe as this was where he was from. The shop of Shop Around the Corner is in Budapest, Hungary. The world this movie is set was on the brink of destruction in 1940 but there is no mention of this in the film. Just like how the film harkens back to a more peaceful time it also acts like a nostalgia portal to a time before the internet or big corporate businesses. A shop which is a physical, hands-on and above all a communal experience. The shop is a world onto its own populated by unforgettable characters.Like Lubitsch, most of Margaret Sullavan's movies also took place in Europe, I don't know of the reason for this, however; a big coincidence or did she deliberately choose to star in movies with European settings? James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan aren't remotely Hungarian but classic Hollywood movies aren't exactly known for their realism in this regard. I also find it humorous how Klara is able to get a job by walking into a store and proving she is capable of selling items; if only it were that easy in real life!The Shop Around the Corner is one of the prime examples of the classic "they hate each other but are really in love"; in fact, they really hate each other. Stewart's Alfred Kralik is actually a real asshole; he's brash and very opinionated. Likewise, Margaret Sullavan isn't a sexy, glamorous Hollywood star; Klara Novak is a down to Earth, intellectual. As the movie progresses you so badly want these two characters to end up together to the point that it hurts. These aren't two performers with great chemistry, these are two performers with incredible lifelike chemistry which blends the dividing line between fiction and reality. If ever there was an on-screen couple how where made for each other, this is it.

reviews.review_title: "I want your opinion, your honest opinion!"
reviews.content: Two feuding co-workers don't realize they are actually romantic pen-pals.Rarely does one find a film a utterly charming as The Shop Around the Corner. Everything about it is just perfect.Jimmy Stewart and Margaret Sullavan are fantastic, and Frank Morgan gives a touching performance. The script is great, with Felix Bressart and William Tracy getting most of the good lines.Highly recommended. First time viewing. 5/5

Some films are totally flawless in their design. They are played with wit, grace and charm-- and they leave you feeling something wonderful, something transcendent, has just happened on screen. Ernst Lubitsch's THE SHOP AROUND THE CORNER is that way.Though filmed entirely on a Hollywood soundstage by MGM, Lubitsch manages to make the production feel European. We know it's not really Budapest-- there are no exteriors shot on location; and most of the accents are no different than those used in other Hollywood films set in foreign locales.But we believe in this story, and we believe in Matuschek and Company, the tiny shop where goods are sold around the corner. It exists in a time and place much less complicated than our world today.The emotional heart of the story is anchored by two would-be lovers named Alfred Kralik (James Stewart) and Klara Novak (Margaret Sullavan). Mr. Kralik has worked for Hugo Matuschek (Frank Morgan) for nine years, having advanced from his original position as a lowly clerk. As the film begins, Miss Novak comes in looking for a job, but Matuschek and Kralik are reluctant to take her on.By some miracle she is able to prove herself as a saleswoman and is subsequently hired. The story moves on from there. Kralik and Novak are now coworkers, and the two forge a bond despite often clashing with one another.Though much of the narrative's focus is on the blossoming relationship between Kralik and Novak, there are plenty of moments that feature the other employees at the shop. All their lives are affected by the boss and by each other. This includes the villain of the piece Ferencz Vadas (Joseph Schildkraut) who we learn early on is having an affair with Matuschek's never seen wife.Most of the romantic elements that occur between the leads are backgrounded during the film's first half. But gradually it comes to the forefront, as we learn Kralik and Novak have been anonymously corresponding with each other. They've fallen in love through their letters to one another, but ironically have come to despise working together.He learns the truth first and withholds this information from her. The moment near the end when she finds out is truly sublime. James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan perform so well in these scenes, there is never any doubt about the characters' real feelings. They appeared in three other films, though this is certainly their most remembered collaboration.The success of Lubitsch's picture cannot be underestimated. Critic Pauline Kael called it the most perfect Hollywood film ever made, praising its delicate pacing and skillful execution. MGM remade it in Technicolor in 1949, as a musical with Judy Garland. In the 1990s it was re-filmed again, updated to reflect a love affair that occurs through emails. Neither one of the remakes have the grace and dignity of the original.

It would be hard to find anything wrong with this movie, which has become such a classic. James Stewart and Margaret Sullivan are wonderful together and the supporting cast just couldn't be any better, each adding their own special touch. Even Rudy, played by Charles Smith, the newest hire at the very end is as sweet as can be. Last night, as I watched the remake, "In the Good Old Summertime", on TCM, I suddenly noticed a familiar face in the quartet singing backup for Judy Garland. There was Charles Smith again! How special that he got to appear in both the original and the remake.

reviews.review_title: This is such a wonderful film and a sweet Christmas story.
reviews.content: Jimmy Stewart is wonderful in this sweet romantic holiday story.This is about a little shop in Budapest Hungary leading up to Christmas. The owner, Mr. Matascheck, views his oldest employee, Mr. Kralik (played by Jimmy Stewart), as a son. He respects him and has invited him home for dinner on multiple occasions. Which is why when he doubts him it is particularly painful. Meanwhile, Mr. Kralik has answered an ad and started a relationship with a woman through letters in which they have agreed to not talk about their jobs or physical appearance. Additionally a down on her luck sales girl comes in to their shop looking for work. The boss gets snookered into hiring her...and right from day one Kralik and the new girl do not get along. This makes for some sweet romantic comedy and this film has all the heartstring tugging that you want in a holiday film that the whole family can enjoy.

Jimmy Stewart gives a sweet, captivating performance as the head salesman of a small-owned bookstore just around the corner in Budapest, Hungary. Margaret Sullivan plays the newest addition to the store's crew and soon these two idealistic young folks begin to contradict each other every time they speak. However, what they don't know is that they have written many letters to each other secretly, not knowing who the other person is but falling for them anyways.As much as I liked the story, and it is so much better than the 1998 remake You've Got Mail, I felt it wasn't one of the best Ernst Lubitsch efforts. It certainly doesn't have the charm or irresistible properties of some of his earlier films and this story is one of the darkest of romantic comedies I have ever seen. Still, with all due respect, Stewart is one of the greatest actors to ever live and the supporting cast is wonderful with Frank Morgan as the store owner and Felix Bressart as Pirovitch. All in all, this has more heart and soul than any of its successors, but I think there is not enough Lubitsch here to make it an absolute classic.

The romantic thread plays out against a very normal but charming backdrop and cast of characters and, above all, with wit. It escapes being overly sentimental and one is just left with positive energy. Some of the best lines and humour are delivered by supporting characters which I think is usually a sign of a great production.The leads, James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan, are both charming and bring to life believable characters. The whole is just flawless.The remake in 1998 is perfectly pleasant but the sheer perfection of this production raises the story to a different level. There is nothing obviously profound about this story but we are being memorably transported to an uplifting vision and warmth in the midst of normal people's lives. In itself, this is profound or can be if we let it.

Honestly, is anyone more charming than Jimmy Stewart? I hadn't seen this movie before but was intrigued when I saw it on a Favourite Christmas Movie list. Fortunately, it was playing on Turner Classic Movie channel, so I settled down after my family's Christmas celebration and just enjoyed! Movies from this era of film are more akin to stage plays than the movies now and I so enjoy the craft of well spoken dialogue. The plot is simple and transparent (it's premise was the inspiration for YOU'VE GOT MAIL). The supporting cast is eclectic and entertaining. I thoroughly enjoyed it. I give this film a 7.9 (enjoyable) out of 10. {Christmas Romantic Drama/Comedy}

I recently bought this movie with a bunch of other LaserDiscs from eBay. Usually, I am into war and action movies but occasionally I enjoy romantic comedies.If you are bored by today's special FX films and high gloss romantic comedies you should check out Shop Around the Corner on a quiet evening. What I like about the movie is that the characters have a lot of decency. There is nothing fake or pretentious about them. Take Mr. Matuschek for example: When he finds out that his wife is cheating on him with one of his own employees he tries to shot himself. Not just because of the humiliation but because he has been unjust to the character of Stewart. (OK, weired example.) Yes, the focus of the movie is narrow and the plot is predictable. Yet still, I liked it a lot. If you liked Notting Hill then you will like Shop around the corner. in fact, Hugh Grant reminds me a lot of Jimmy Stewart.

reviews.review_title: The first time is always the best
reviews.content: I love watching movies, and I find that I am turning more and more to the 'classics' section of my video store for the type of entertainment I am willing to sit through. It seems that everyone has run out of new, fun and creative ideas and are  making more and more remakes of old classics. Today we are deluged with promotional material for the new movie "you've got mail" but I would much rather watch the original film 'the shop around the corner'.  It is funny, charming and full of wit and although it may have a more laid-back feel to it, I found it infinitely superior. If you want to get away from the Hollywoodization of the old classics, find this movie in your local video store and enjoy!

Once you get over the fact that thought the movie is set in Vienna and all of the characters have Austrian-sounding names -- but everyone speaks in English (some accented and some not) -- the story is almost too cute for words; but in a nice way. It's a twist on the now standard, boy meets girl; boy likes girl; girls dislikes boy; girl and boy get together and live . . . you get the picture. The performances by Stewart and Sullivan and the pacing of the movie take you beyond all that and make you root like crazy for boy and girl.This movie is a classic, and deservedly so, in spite of its very ordinary premise. The whole is a lot more than the sum of the parts in this gem.

Otherwise known as the inspiration for the 90s Hanks/Ryan vehicle You've Got Mail, it's a little hard for us kids of the 21st Century to imagine how the concept is done through snail mail. But I shouldn't underestimate the economy of Ernst Lubitsch who skims through time and teases what's happened offscreen and keeps his sequences tightly under wraps with big events occurring within a scene. Only Lubitsch could make James Stewart a despicable person, balanced out by Stewart's natural likability. I wanted to like The Shop Around The Corner more given that it's very popular among those who made it but maybe it'll grow on me. I did love its idea of love not being superficial. Warmed my heart by its end. I'm falling for Lubitsch.8/10

reviews.review_title: Cannot Empathize with Characters, Too Many Nasty Characters
reviews.content:
This move was the inspiration for "You've Got Mail" which is a far better movie in every way. Most of the problem lies with the nasty, hateful characters.Alfred Kralik (James Stewart): Kralik is an affable character who is misunderstood and insulted by Klara. There is no logical reason for her behavior except that she is a b***** at heart who misrepresented herself in her letters. Poor Kralik, deludes himself into thinking he loves her when he really loves the false persona she generated in her letters. Stewart's performance is average, but still apropos for the character.Klara Novak (Margaret Sullavan):
Shrill voiced shrew who hurled a constant and unending barrage of hateful insults at Alfred Kralik (Jimmy Stewart). She misinterpreted everything he said to her as some kind of insult and responded with hateful biting insults. She continued this right up until the end of the movie. I don't know how the viewer is supposed to believe she wrote the kinds of letter she supposedly wrote given her abominable behavior. There was no reason for her behavior other than the fact that she is a thoroughly nasty person. People regularly misrepresent themselves online and obviously did the same back when they communicated by letter, as klara did. The ending where he looks at his legs and kisses him passionately is the most stupid romantic endings in any movie I have EVER seen!Pepe Katona:
A thoroughly unlikeable character who shows his true colors when he gets the promotion for saving Mr. Matuschek's life. He is a small insignificant man (boy") with delusions of grandeur about his self-worth. In addition, he was supposed to keep the attempted suicide of Mr. Matuschek and the reason for it secret, but he blurts it all out in front of everyone when he talks to Mrs. Matuschek. In addition, he had no way of knowing the she had an affair with Mr. Vadas, since that was told to Mr. Kralik in strictest confidence, yet he implies that is what happened in the same phone call. Beyond that, the re does not seem to be any surprise among the other employees when they hear the phone call, as if they all already knew the whole story.Ferencz Vadas:
While a dislikable character, at least he was portrayed honestly and not misrepresented as a good guy. The viewer immediately disliked him the moment he spoke for the very first time. He was a preening egotistical man with delusions of self grandeurs, much like Pepe, except he was portrayed honestly as the villain of the piece.Hugo Matuschek (Frank Morgan):
The first hurdle with this character is getting over the urge to see him as the Wizard in the Wizard of Oz. His character is thoroughly likeable and we are all sympathetic to his travails. He comes across as the kindly old uncle who looks out for the welfare of his relatives. There is, however, some bad and contradictory writing of his character. He confesses to Kralik that he has hated him for a very long time because he thought he was having an affair with his wife, but he invited him to his home for dinner, and talked warmly about making Kralik a partner in the store. In fact, he is very friendly to Kralik throughout the movie until the scene where he dismisses him. It looks like the writers were just making up whatever suited their story line at that point in the movie without regard to continuity, very bad writing.This is a very badly written movie, with all kinds of plot holes and errors that are never fixed. It is also a very dark and depressing movie in spite of the attempt to make it a romantic and warm Christmas movie. We have poor Kralik about to marry Klara based on the lies she wrote in her letters. Mr. Matuschek while giving from his heart as he offers Christmas dinner to the delivery boy, still has to deal with the infidelity of his wife leading to his attempted suicide.You may want to watch this movie just to see the inspiration for "You've Got mail", but rest assured "You've Got Mail" is a much better movie, with thoroughly likeable characters, especially Meg Ryan's character who shows genuine empathy and remorse when she insults Joe Fox. The romantic end is much more heartwarming and actually brought me to tears which is a very difficult thing to do.I am overly generous giving this movie even two stars.

Starring James Stewart and Margaret Sullivan, this story is what "You've Got Mail" is based on. Only this is much better.For one thing, there's no profanity. For another, it has my favorite actor, James Stewart.Alfred Kralik (Stewart) and Klara Novak (Sullivan) know each other by both mail and real life. By letter, they're in love. By real life, they loath each other.Alfred's boss (Frank Morgan, "The Wizard of Oz") thinks that Alfred is after his wife. So he fires Allfred, but then he gets sick, so he tells Alfred that he's the new manager. Meanwhile, Alfred and Klara find out that they secretly love each other.I have only seen this movie once, and that was over a year ago, so I don't remember the exact ending. But if you like Jimmy Stewart, you'll love this movie.My Score: 8/10.

If you have seen 'You've Got Mail' (I found 'You've Got Mail' to be a good remake), then you will understand the plot of this movie as this is the original. The story revolves around the shop around the corner - being "Matuschek's" and all the employees there. The owner, played by Frank Morgan is a likable chap despite his harsh temper at times. Then there is Mr Kralik, played by James Stewart, who is in love with a woman who has been corresponding with via letters... who he's never met. He has been there for nine years and is one of the most beloved employees... until Klara Novak (Maragret Sullavan) comes along! I was very surprised at how much I was laughing in this movie - there are some very cute and heart warming moments. I didn't think it would be this good, and completely exceeded my expectations. There is a timeless feeling of the characters, in fact the whole movie. I like how the romance subtly develops, and you can see it. There are truly beautiful performances all around - by every one of the cast. This sets the standard for every movie in this era and is, no doubt, superior to its remakes. A very beautiful movie, perfect for Christmas time. Film-making at its best.

reviews.review_title: One of the best classic movies ever made
reviews.content: This movie is so good. It's entertaining from start to finish and I truly never got bored. The jokes are on point and are just as funny today as they were back the I'm sure. I enjoyed all the characters and you really get invested in each one them. The story is cute, and really reminds me of how crass getting to know people can be even 80 years ago. Jimmy Stewart is amazing as always, and this is def one of his best early movies. I could go on telling you how much I love it, but you should watch and decide for yourself! I definitely would rate this on the top 10 romantic comedies though. Great for a watch by yourself, and probably even better with your partner if ya have one. Enjoy it, I know I did!

reviews.review_title: Another Jimmy Stewart classic - a must see for his fans
reviews.content: I don't think there is a Stewart movie that I don't like (except maybe "Anatomy Of A Murder). This movie rates up there with some of my favorites. I think what makes this movie good is not only the compelling story, but the exceptional character development. This movie is so rich with such a wide range of characters, and I think the casting choices were superb.The main problem I have with the film however, is the whole Budapest angle. Not a single person speaks with an accent and are all very American. But yet all the signs in the shop are written in Hungarian ( I presume). But not a single customer coming in the shop speaks a foreign language or even has an accent. Perhaps this was characteristic of movies of that day, but I found it distracting. Why not rewrite it as taking place in New York, or Chicago, or Wichita for that matter.A very good film - a must see for any Stewart fan.

I had not heard about this movie until AFI's 100 Years 100 Romances list came out.  It is hard to find at the video store and I feel blessed to have found it at my local library.  It is an understated Romantic Comedy with some bite and meanness not normally found in classic movies.  It was remade into a musical in 1949 and then again in 1998 as "You Got Mail."  I actually preferred this over the Tom Hanks/Meg Ryan version.  It is more believable that the two romantic leads can overcome their dislike for each other and fall in love.  Also, Jimmy Stewart's character is much more likable than the one Tom Hanks plays in "You Got Mail." It is a shame that more people have not heard of this great Jimmy Stewart movie.

Another Samson Raphaelson script for Lubitsch. I believe that's what makes the movie outdated (I'm comparing with the script for Trouble in Paradise). Fortunately there's James Stewart and he is perfect for that role. The plot itsef is very good (Tom Hanks could send e-mails to his neighbor, a simple-minded gay castaway on the Web) and the supporting actors are quite good. Still the narration is not so nimble as it should have been all along. Sometimes the quality of simplicity you'd never deny for those movies (comedies of the 30s-40s) appears more like a flaw. Depends on how much you are ready to think of what was cinema by then.

This is another one of those films which could be called a "minor classic". The story is timeless (with echoes of Dickens' "A Christmas Carol") and the performances are sympathetic, but it's too much like the play it was based on to make it a true classic. Having lived in Hungary it's weird seeing Hungarian signs and hearing Hungarian names in a Hollywood movie, and that adds something extra to my enjoyment of it.

reviews.review_title: Destiny has its own funny ways
reviews.content: On January 12th 1940 a little movie came to the theaters and it was Ernst Lubitsch's masterpiece "The shop around the corner", marvelous feel-good romantic comedy about two lost souls in this world who were looking for each other in all the wrong places. The movie's main characters are portrayed by the great James Stewart and wonderful Margaret Sullavan and just by looking at the two of them you feel their chemistry right away. Outstanding performances. And so are everyone else's; the secondary characters have their stories as well - they open up to the viewer, make us care for them, fall in love with them, empathize with them and it all happens in the runtime of just less than a 100 minutes; most of 200 minute movies nowadays cannot offer even the main character's full disclosure.Watching movies like "The shop around the corner" makes me feel alive and thinking that destiny has its own funny ways of playing this strange little game called life. You can dream of a perfect person who will adore you, love you, make you feel beautiful and pretty but it wouldn't be the same as having a real one by your side, and where can you find such person? Oh, maybe he's just around the corner, or seats right by you on a subway train, or stands right behind you in the line to get a latte. Don't you ever underestimate fate, folks, I tell you, because one of these days when you least expect it you will be punched right in your face by the fist of fate - and you will feel great about it.I have always loved James and I always will - I consider "The shop around the corner" one of his finest performances ever but Margaret shines the brightest here; I would surely love to dig into her filmography as well and see what else this remarkable actress has got to offer. The best thing about this movie is that it lets you live in it and you feel like you belong in its world wholeheartedly.

reviews.review_title: A really watchable rom com for modern audiences. Short and engaging, a nice cosy film around christmas time
reviews.content: This is such a lovely film. I think unless you are really into them and used to the style, classical hollywood films before 1960 feel very distant to modern audiences and can sometimes be tricky to engage if they are not well known classics like the wizard of oz. This film was really watchable for 1940 however and really fun. It is a simple romantic story set around Christmas time which is short and has no filler and makes you smile. What's remarkable is that it has all the rom com tropes despite it being 80 years old. If Ryan Reynolds and Sandra Bullock were in it it would be exactly the same film. So it is very watchable for modern audiences. I recommend to watch around christmas time.
This Movie is a perfect romance, this Movie is something that you can cry with, and also laugh, a comedy and perfect Classic romance.You will never be regret for watching this master peace.

The only thing that keeps this movie from being completely satisfying is Margaret Sullavan. She has absolutely no sex appeal, and very little anything-else appeal. Jimmy Stewart is wonderful and of course any girl would fall for him, but poor Margaret can't come across as anything but a snide brat. Frank Morgan, Felix Bressart, Sara Haden, Joseph Shildkraut, and William Tracy are all perfect in their supporting roles.The musical version of this film "In the Good Old Summertime" with Van Johnson and Judy Garland is far superior in every way, despite the odd title. However, "Shop Around the Corner" itself is far superior to "You've Got Mail," a dreary, lengthy, rather mean-spirited copy.Point of interest: Look for Charles Smith as Rudy, the new delivery boy, at the end of the film. Mr. Smith also appeared, uncredited, in "The Good Old Summertime" as the youngest and tallest member of the mustachioed barbershop quartet.

reviews.review_title: Honestly not as good as I had hoped
reviews.content: "The Shop Around the Corner" has one of the greatest plots for a romantic comedy ever. You know it already if you'll seen the remake, "You've Got Mail." A man and woman who dislike each other in person are unknowingly corresponding to each other as pen pals and are falling in love with someone they think they've never met. Being that "You've Got Mail," is one of my favorite romance comedies of all time, I expected that I would love this film as well. Unfortunately, this version did not work as well as I would have liked. Unlike the remake, this film does not keep us and the main characters in suspense, waiting and wishing for them to finally fall in love. Several subplots also put burdens on the light-hearted nature the film should have, as the remake did. The film has too many upsetting moments, such as job losses, nervous breakdowns, and Jimmy Stewart's boss (Frank Morgan, the Wizard of "Wizard of Oz") learning his wife is having an affair. I prefer this film as the fun, romantic story it turned out to be in the remake. Jimmy Stewart and Margret Sullivan make excellent stars, but the supporting cast is not as good or appealing as I would like. If you don't mind a romantic story like this mixed in with more serious moments, you will probably enjoy this. If you want a more carefree and romantic film, as I did, this one may not be for you. Enjoyable at times, but fairly disappointing for me.Nevertheless, *** out of ****

reviews.review_title: I'm a Lubitsch fan, but not a fan of this film
reviews.content: I have a passion for the great movies and stars of early Hollywood, and at this point I have seen many dozens (possibly hundreds) of gems from the '30s and '40s. Ernst Lubitsch is one of my favorite directors, yet somehow I have just gotten around to watching this highly touted movie. I'll admit upfront that I have never been a James Stewart fan, though I don't deny the greatness of films like Rear Window, Vertigo, Anatomy of a Murder, ... (the list could go on and on). I was expecting to be similarly impressed with this movie, given all that has been said about it. Instead, it left me cold.The story is a little silly, but that didn't bother me in The Merry Widow or The Smiling Lieutenant. The acting was very good, but I was thinking throughout the movie that I would have liked it better with two different leads. As a whole, it just didn't click for me, and I have no desire to see it again. For me, the two movies mentioned at the beginning of this paragraph, along with Trouble in Paradise and Ninotchka, are far superior examples of "the Lubitsch touch". One fan's opinion.

William Tracy's character (Pepe) in this film is THE most annoying character in the history of film. Unbearable!Besides Tracy's portrayal of Pepe how did this movie get an 8.1 rating? There's way too much over-acting and shouting.

I saw this for the first time last night on Turner Classic Movies. I was struck by the similarity of the characters and much of the plot line to "Little House of Horrors." Steve Martin's dentist could have been the man who seduced the wife of the shop owner. Audrey could have been Miss Novak, etc. The owners of both shops were almost twins, even having similar names. Maybe I'm crazy, but these two movies are from the same, or at least parallel, universes.Jimmy Stewart gave a great performance as the clerk. I especially liked the kid who played Rudy--a small but critical part that gave the little shop a future, while the old errand boy started his climb to eventfully manage the place. Real life showed up in this film.

They don't air this gem all too often, but it remains one of my favorite Christmas movies. James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan head up an excellent cast of people working in a leather goods store during the Christmas season. Some interesting surprises are in store for the viewer, but the Stewart-Sullavan interplay drives this delightful old film forward. Frank Morgan is the owner of the 'shop' and delivers his role beautifully. TCM shows it from time to time.
I like this movie and I am proud of it. Its a very simple love story when the times were simpler. Also its funny.Also I think that James Stewart is a very sexy man.

reviews.review_title: All the ingredients of a true classic
reviews.content: Here's an example of how a classic movie should be crafted. It didn't hurt that Ernst Lubitsch was at the helm, presiding over a talented cast headed by Stewart and Margaret Sullavan, an actress whose work should be better remembered. In previous years, the two stars had gained a lot of experience in the same the community-theater circuits, and their chemistry here is genuine. Sure, the movie is pushing a century old....everybody is polite and they call each other "Mr" and "Miss"....any conflicts are handled without foul language, violence or bawdy conversation....and what a well-acted, expertly directed, gentle pleasure it is. If you appreciate the Golden Age of movies, don't miss this little gem.

Ernst Lubitsch was one of the main references of Hollywood romantic comedy in the 30s and 40s (until his death in 1947). This The Shop Around the Corner, from 1940, is already part of the final stage of his career, with other great hits such as Ninotchka or To Be Or Not to Be.With James Stewart leading the cast, this is a story of the common man, humble shopkeepers, with their frugal lives and small dreams, poetically elevated to the role of everyday heroes.A fun and positive film, very well written and capable of raising the viewer's morale and good mood, even more than 80 years after it was made, due to its humanism and intelligence.

reviews.review_title: More romance than comedy, but still tops
reviews.content: In the wide range of the Lubitsch touch, The Shop Around The Corner most certainly falls more deeply in the romance category than the comedic side, represented by his other masterpieces like To Be Or Not To Be. As another reviewer said, this is one of the saddest romantic comedies around, but we'll all be happy to know that the screenwriter couldn't help but put in a few clever quips that Lubitsch is so wonderfully known for. The script could easily be one of the tightest scripts of all time, and it is admirable how much mileage they get out of a single room and few relationships. I highly suggest this film to anyone who finds joy in simple stories made fun through the sheer mastery of the craft of film.
Wonderful movie for Christmas time. It is just a nice movie to watch with a sweet ending. You got mail took the idea of it as well. Perfect for all ages.

reviews.review_title: Enjoyable, though I prefer the Tom Hanks version
reviews.content:
"The Shop Around the Corner" is the movie on which the Tom Hanks / Meg Ryan film, "You've Got Mail" is based.  My wife and I enjoyed the Hanks film a great deal and, as I am a big fan of Jimmy Stewart, I expected to like the original even more.  Alas, in this I was disappointed.  Stewart is excellent as Alfred Kralik and Margaret Sullivan makes a good foil for his efforts as Klara Novak, but overall the movie falls short of what it could have been. 
There are really two stories going on in this movie:  Kralik's anonymous postbox relationship with Klara Novak, and Kralik's pseudo father/son relationship with his employer, Mr. Matuschek (Frank Morgan).  This means that the script must make room for both stories, the result of which is that neither is as fully developed as it could be.  This is most evident at the end, when we learn -- in what comes off as a very artificial rush -- that Klara has been attracted to Alfred all along and was (supposedly) faking her dislike for him as a means of attracting his attention.  This Deus-ex-machina contrivance is necessary in order to produce the required Happy Ending when Alfred reveals to Klara that he is the letter writer whom she has pined over.Nora Ephron's adaptation of this story avoids this pitfall by sticking with only one story -- the two-sided relationship between the Hanks and Ryan. She was thus able to permit Meg Ryan's character much more time to change her view of Hanks, and Hanks more time to woo her to that changed point of view.  The result was a more believable Happy Ending (to the extent, of course, that any Hollywood Happy Endings are believable!).I also found the supposed setting (pre-war Budapest) to be a similar contrivance.  As a Hungarian, Miklos Laszlo's decision to set the play in pre-war Budapest is understandable.  But when the movie was cast with the all-American stars Stewart, Sullivan, and Morgan, a New York or Chicago setting would have been much more credible.Disappointment aside, though, this is still a fun film to watch.  As I said at the beginning, Jimmy Stewart acts with his usual brilliance, and Margaret Sullivan and Frank Morgan complement him very well.  So do go ahead and get this on DVD if you are a Jimmy Stewart fan or a lover of romantic comedies. The Shop Around the Corner is not perfect, but it is pleasant.  I, for one, like pleasant.

The Shop around the Corner is never dull, never boring and absolutely not as silly as one could expect of a comedy 60 years old. It´s new remake, You´ve Got Mail, adds few bits and pieces, which possibly make it more intricate, but the mood is partially gone. It´s a classic heartwarming, feel good movies that has you smiling thoughtlessly, that simply aren´t being made anymore. Two thumbs up!

This movie was ok but not the best. Jimmy Stewart gives a good performance but I really wasn't impressed with Sullavan. She seemed to be whining for most of the film. The other charactors were pretty good. It drags at times but overall it's a good film.

"The Shop Around the Corner" is a good film. I love the story which has been used in 2 other movies to follow. But out of the three movies(Shop Around The Corner, In The Good Old Summertime, You've Got Mail) I like this one the least. Stewart gives a good performance as usual but Sullivan who plays the girl isn't that appealing. At some points she gets so annoying and whiny that you almost hope they don't end up together. The supporting cast gives good laughs and keeps you entertained most of the time. This movie does have more plot than the other two and the supporting characters are not just "window dressing". It's a good film, worth seeing if you have the time, but definitely check out the other two versions and make your own judgment.
Simply splendid and romantic. I watched this years ago when I was a teenager. I thought it was okay but now as a grown woman I enjoyed it. One of my faves with Jimmy.

Lubtisch beautifully tells his stories. 
This simple movie transcends genre or style and is instead a morality tale. Only the great masters can achieve this level of simplicity and legacy.
